thread.title: Volleyball continues postseason play in state playoffs
thread.title_full: Volleyball continues postseason play in state playoffs

author: E. Marcel Pourtout mpourtout@neighbornewspapers.com (noreply@neighbornewspapers.com)
title: Volleyball continues postseason play in state playoffs
text: Volleyball continues postseason play in state playoffs by E. Marcel Pourtout October 21, 2015 02:05 PM | 247 views | 0 | | Special PhotoThe Cambridge volleyball team captured the Area 7 tournament championship with a 3-1 home win over Sequoyah on Oct. 10. Following the match, several Bears’ players and coaches were honored. Pictured, from left to right, Sterling Hines (All-Area selection and Player of the Year), Lauren Swift (All-Area selection), Katie Johnson (Coach of the Year), Regan Swift (All-Area selection) and Ellah Klinnert (All-Area selection). slideshow This week, the prep volleyball season enters the second round of the state playoffs with several local programs contending for a championship beginning on Oct. 20. Each team’s first-round contest took place on Thursday, Oct. 15.Cambridge out of Class 5A followed up its region championship with a 3-0 home victory over Union Grove in the first round. Sophomore Sterling Hines had a team-high 12 kills while junior Lauren Swift (11 kills) and sophomore Ellah Klinnert (10 kills) also reached double-digits. Senior Alex Wright has a team-high 14 digs while Hines notched 13 digs for a double-double. Sophomore Anna Youngs’ three aces were a team-high as well as junior Olivia Hanson’s 22 assists.“We didn’t know much about Union Grove before our match, so we talked about staying focused and controlling the balls that we could control on our side of the net,” Cambridge coach Katie Johnson said. “We served aggressively, continued to mix up our offense the way we’ve been practicing, and it paid off with a win.”The Bears, who have won 29 contests this season, will host South Effingham out of Guyton in the second round. The Mustangs have won 39 contests this season and won their first-round match over Greenbrier 3-0.Defending state champions Blessed Trinity opened up defense of its Class 3A title with a 3-0 home win over Coahulla Creek in the first round. Senior Olivia Dukat had a team-high nine kills for the Titans while sophomore Hanley Lomax notched six of the team’s 15 total aces. Emma Simonsen, Anna MacDonald and Annie Dempsey each had five digs and Juliet Medley’s nine assists led the team.Blessed Trinity has won 38 matches this year and makes a trip to south Georgia for its second round contest against Savannah Arts Academy. The Panthers have won 29 matches and defeated Cedartown 3-0 in the first round.Fellowship Christian, which has earned 32 wins this season, advanced to the second round in Class A with a 3-0 home win over Strong Rock Christian. Junior Shelby Villar had a game-high 10 digs and eight kills for the Paladins in the win. Rebekah Mann’s 21 assists were a game-high as well.Fellowship Christian will host Savannah Country Day in the second round after the Hornets defeated Stratford Academy 3-0 in the first round. The Paladins come into the contest with 32 wins while Savannah Country Day has 20 victories.Johns Creek won its first round match in Acworth against defending state champion North Cobb 3-0. Senior Mikaela Gauthreaux had a game-high 20 kills while sophomore Crystal Childs had 12 for the Gladiators. Five Johns Creek players had double-digit digs including a team-high 16 from senior Madeline Savage and 11 from Gauthreaux giving her a double-double. The Gladiators have won 38 contests this season and visit Walton in Marietta for their second-round contest.St. Francis out of Class A made the postseason for the first time in program history after winning 14 matches this season. The Knights saw its year come to an end in the first round of the postseason with a 3-0 defeat at Eagles Landing Christian Academy in McDonough. Sophomore Alexis Ratiff had a team-high nine kills for St. Francis while senior Yasmeet Ratliff had six. Nichel Tampa finished with a team-high 17 assists for the Knights.“We had a great season,” St. Francis coach Aisha Kennedy said. “The girls know now that we can compete and win so we’ll continue to change the culture and work on being a solid fundamental team.” Two Class 6A programs saw their seasons conclude in the first round. Alpharetta finished the season with 33 wins 3-1 defeat to Harrison in Kennesaw. Chattahoochee’s 2015 campaign concluded with 16 wins on a 3-1 loss at North Gwinnett.Mount Pisgah also ended its season in the first round of the Class A playoffs with a 3-0 loss at Landmark Christian.
